content: hey everyone why lock here welcome back
thanks for joining me quick little project today with a toy
that a lot of you are probably familiar with this was intended to be chaos
scatter terrain but I have ended up using them in my Dungeons & Dragons
games as spell effects and encounters and things like that this project took
about an hour it's a good example of how to harvest stuff from toys so let me
show you how I did it infinite thanks to my patreon patrons
and remember that our sponsor is heroes hoard for you 3d printers out there
excellent selection including Altru tiles lines this is a Star Wars Wrath
tart toy usually around 10 bucks I got it as a gift last year at mace been
holding onto it ever since so I took the tentacles trimmed off the nub that would
connect to the body and hot glued them to a chipboard base chipboard is the
brown slab at the back of a legal pad but you can buy it in bulk like I do
links in the video description below anyway I took some cork sheeting that
got this from the crafting store it's about 1/4 inch thick just broke off
chunks and hot glue them to the base around the tentacle making sure that
they're kind of wedge-shaped so that all the chipboard is hidden and it looks
like the tentacle is bursting from the ground now this is pretty weak at the
moment so I painted on some white PVA glue such as Elmer's solid thick coat a
few hours later hard as a rock out to the garage for primer Kryolan and
rust-oleum both make fine matte spray primers to thin coats applied one hour
apart and let it sit overnight to fully cure then I got out my airbrush and laid
down a light green base coat says Vallejo over day s core pinna and with a
darker green I hit the bottom quarter or so of the tentacle starting a nice
gradient pink is next did the top half of the
tentacle with that and finally a rich magenta sort of color here they are all
base coated looking good so far wanted to shade them to bring out the
detail so I thought to use a green wash and a purple wash first the green with a
soft bristled brush and then the purple however the purple came out looking a
bit too dark kind of messy and besides when I look at it side by side without
the purple actually liked it better so I rebase coated that first one and only
use the green wash on all of them for the busted ground with cheap acrylic
craft paints I simply base coated with black then dry brushed with a dark grey
and then some random edge Nix with a very light gray I intend to use these on
a variety of different paddle mattes different environments so just gray
stone should look fine on anything back outside for sealant I like krylon
crystal clear flat spray sealer short bursts from about 12 inches away to make
sure that the accelerant chemical doesn't accumulate and eat the paint
again two thin coats of this makes for excellent protection now let's look at
the final product and hey if you dig this content why not like subscribe and
reminder bail and here's a few all finished next to some miniatures for
scale toy came with 12 tentacles so I made all 12 of them I've used these to
represent spell effects in my D&D games and as Kaos scatter terrain in my
Warhammer 40k games really should work in any sort of eldritch or alien sort of
setting Call of Cthulhu even likely next episode I have some more really cool
chaos based scatter terrain and don't forget you can see my terrain in action
in battle reports on my sister YouTube channel why lock plays if you like this
particular project here's two more you might want to check out also enjoy this
community show I'm wild luck thanks for joining and
I'll see you next time
